para.phrase: SUSAN M. BUTLER-WU AND ROSEMARY C. SHE

sect2.title: TAXONOMY AND DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENTS
sect2.para: Anaerobic, Gram-positive, non-spore-forming bacilli (rods) are widely distributed among the phylaActinomycetota (formerly Actinobacteria) and Bacillota (formerly Firmicutes). Even though these phyla include both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, this chapter focuses on the latter, although a number of these bacteria are also facultative. Additionally, some members of this group of bacteria can stain Gram negative despite possessing a Gram-positive cell wall. It should also be noted that rare species within these taxonomic groups are spore forming and are included in this chapter. Many anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods have undergone some degree of taxonomic reclassification over the years because of 16S rRNA gene sequencing. However, since the publication of the last edition of this Manual, phylogenomic analyses resulting from whole-genome sequencing (WGS) studies have resulted in the wide-scale taxonomic reclassification of numerous genera in this chapter. Nevertheless, despite this taxonomic reclassification, so long as a previously used name remains validly published it can continue to be used.

The number of genera within the broad category of anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods is vast. Thus, bacteria discussed in this chapter are limited to those isolated from human sources and considered validly published; invalidly published bacteria in this group are not discussed. Finally, metagenomic characterization of the human microbiome by next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods has continued to lead to the discovery of novel genera within both phylaActinomycetota and Bacillota. This group of bacteria will therefore continue to expand as metagenomics is applied in even wider settings.

sect2.title: Class Actinobacteria
sect2.para: Clinically relevant anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods in this class belong to the ordersActinomycetales, Propionibacteriales, and Bifidobacteriales. The traditional genera Actinomyces, Actinobaculum, Actinotignum, Mobiluncus, and Varibaculum all belong to the family Actinomycetaceae. This family contains both anaerobic and aerotolerant, Gram-positive organisms with variable morphology, ranging from characteristic branching rods to coccobacilli.

The large degree of taxonomic heterogeneity among members of the genusActinomyces has been recognized for some time. At the time of writing, there are over 30 officially recognized species of Actinomyces. Phylogenomic analyses have led to the recent reclassification of many Actinomyces species into seven new genera, with the clinically important pathogens being limited to five genera (1). These new clinically relevant genera include Bowdenia nasicola (Actinomyces nasicola), Pauljensenia hongkongensis (Actinomyces hongkongensis), Winkia neuii (alternatively named Actinomyces neuii), and Gleimia species (comprising three species, including the alternatively named Actinomyces europaeus). Several clinically important Actinomyces species have now been reclassified as members of the genus Schaalia, including the alternatively named bacteria Actinomyces meyeri, Actinomyces radingae, Actinomyces odontolyticus, and Actinomyces turicensis.

Two alternatively named members of the genusActinobaculum (Actinobaculum schaalii and Actinobaculum urinale) were previously reclassified into the genus Actinotignum, with a third species (Actinotignum sanguinis) also described (2–4). The genus Mobiluncus contains three species, Mobiluncus curtisii, Mobiluncus mulieris, and Mobiluncus holmesii, which are strictly anaerobic, curved bacilli with variable Gram stain reactions. M. curtisii and M. holmesii are typically short, curved rods, whereas M. mulieris often appears as long, straight or slightly curved rods (5). The genus Varibaculum comprises Varibaculum cambriense (6) and Varibaculum anthropi (7) along with the recently described Varibaculum massiliense (8), Varibaculum timonense (9), and Varibaculum vaginae (10). These species are short, diphtheroid rods that can be straight or curved. V. massiliense appears to be relatively genomically different from other members of the genus and is likely to undergo taxonomic revision in the future.

The familyPropionibacteriaceae contains over 25 distinct genera, of which seven have been isolated from humans. Propionibacterium is the type genus of these anaerobic and aerotolerant, pleomorphic, branching, Gram-positive rods that produce propionic acid from glucose. The genus Propionibacterium previously contained bacteria isolated both from human sources and dairy products (i.e., so-called “classical propionibacteria”). However, recognition that the cutaneous species form a distinct clade within this genus led to significant taxonomic reclassification of this genus (11). Thus, Propionibacterium acnes, Propionibacterium granulosum, and Propionibacterium avidum were reclassified as members of the genus Cutibacterium. The previously unofficially recognized species “Propionibacterium humerusii” (12) has now been officially renamed Cutibacterium modestum (13). Propionibacterium propionicum, which can cause actinomycosis, was originally reclassified as Pseudopropionibacterium propionicum (11), but on further analysis, this name was recently deemed illegitimate, and the organism has now reverted to its original name Arachnia propionica (14). Other closely related organisms within the family Propionibacteriaceae that have been isolated from humans include Propionimicrobium lymphophilum and Propioniferax innocua, both of which were previously considered members of the genus Propionibacterium. P. lymphophilum appears as both club-shaped rods and coccoid forms, while P. innocua is a pleomorphic rod that is arranged in clusters and V forms. Of the three newly described genera in the family Propionibacteriaceae isolated from humans, Enemella and Parenemella generally appear as coccobacilli (15), whereas cells of Vaginimicrobium are pleomorphic or club-shaped rods that tend to appear singly (16).

Bifidobacterium and the closely related genera Alloscardovia (17), Parascardovia, and Scardovia (18) belong to the family Bifidobacteriaceae. These Gram-positive, pleomorphic rods can range from being uniform in shape to branched or club shaped. Similarly, these organisms vary from strictly anaerobic to occasionally microaerobic, the latter being the case for members of the genus Alloscardovia. There are currently over 35 Bifidobacterium species, of which over 10 have been isolated from the human gut and oral cavity. Bifidobacterium longum now includes the alternatively named species Bifidobacterium infantis and Bifidobacterium suis as subspecies (19).

sect2.title: Class Coriobacteriia
sect2.para: The familiesAtopobiaceae and Coriobacteriaceae within the order Coriobacteriales contain a sizeable number of clinically important members, including the traditional genera of Atopobium, Olsenella, and Collinsella (20). Phylogenomic analyses have led to significant taxonomic reclassification within both families since the last edition of this Manual. Several species within the genus Atopobium had been misassigned to various genera (e.g., Lactobacillus and Eubacterium) within the phylum Bacillota; phylogenetic analyses have resulted in only three species remaining in the genus Atopobium, with the most clinically relevant species Atopobium parvulum, Atopobium rimae, and Atopobium vaginae having been reclassified as Lancefieldella rimae, Lancefieldella parvula, and Fannyhessea vaginae, respectively (1). These three genera are small, elongated Gram-positive coccobacilli that produce lactic acid as their major metabolic end product.

There has been a recent expansion of species within the closely related genusOlsenella, with three newly described species (Olsenella massiliensis, Olsenella phocaeensis, and Olsenella urininfantis) (21) along with the original genus members Olsenella uli and Olsenella profusa. In addition, two members of the genus Olsenella have now been reclassified as Paratractidigestivibacter faecalis and Tractidigestivibacter scatoligenes, along with two novel genera within the family Atopobiaceae named Thermophilibacter and Parolsenella (22). Within the family Coriobacteriaceae, Collinsella has six described species that are coccoid rods which can form chains (23). Enorma and Senegalimassilia are novel genera within this family that have been isolated from human stool, the latter of which are coccobacilli (24).

The familyEggerthellaceae is the sole family within the order Eggerthellales. The genus Eggerthella is composed of Eggerthella lenta, Eggerthella sinensis, and Eggerthella guodeyinii, with Eggerthella hongkongensis now reclassified as the sole member of the genus Paraeggerthella (25, 26). Both genera are Gram-positive rods that occur singly or in pairs or short chains. Other genera within the order Eggerthellales that have been isolated from humans include Adlercreutzia (coccobacilli and rods) (27), Cryptobacterium (short bacilli) (28), Ellagibacter (short rods) (29), Enteroscipio (rods), Gordonibacter (coccobacilli) (30), Rubneribacter (rods) (31), and Slackia (Gram-variable rods) (25).

sect2.title: Class Bacilli
sect2.para: The familyLactobacillaceae, in the order Lactobacillales, previously consisted of only three genera, Lactobacillus, Paralactobacillus, and Pediococcus, the largest among these by far being the genus Lactobacillus. Lactobacillus was a large and heterogeneous genus containing microaerobic, catalase-negative, non-spore-forming, Gram-positive rods, producing lactic acid as their single or major metabolic end product from glucose fermentation. The phylogenetic relationship between the diverse species within this genus was previously recognized as complicated and in need of additional studies to better illuminate the classification of lactobacilli. Large-scale analyses of published lactobacilli genomes have now been completed, resulting in massive reclassification of this genus; of the over 260 Lactobacillus species previously described, only 42 species remain (32). Of the 23 novel genera described as part of this reclassification, clinically relevant alternatively named members of the Lactobacillus are now found within the following six genera: Lacticaseibacillus (includes Lacticaseibacillus paracasei and Lacticaseibacillus rhamnosus), Lactiplantibacillus (includes Lactiplantibacillus plantarum), Latilactobacillus, Levilactobacillus, Ligilactobacillus (includes Ligilactobacillus salivarius and several motile species), and Limosilactobacillus (includes the alternatively named Lactobacillus reuteri group). Species remaining within the genus Lactobacillus that have been isolated from humans include Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus crispatus, Lactobacillus delbrueckii, Lactobacillus fornicalis, Lactobacillus gallinarum, Lactobacillus gasseri, Lactobacillus iners, Lactobacillus jensenii, Lactobacillus johnsonii, Lactobacillus kalixensis, Lactobacillus mulieris, Lactobacillus paragasseri, Lactobacillus pasteurii, and Lactobacillus ultunensis. Lactobacilli are typically Gram-positive rods with a propensity to form short chains. However, Loigolactobacillus coryniformis forms short coccoid rods, that are frequently pear shaped and vancomycin susceptible and can be isolated from pulmonary infections (33).

sect2.title: Class Clostridia
sect2.para: Within the orderEubacteriales, the genus Eubacterium has traditionally served as a repository for anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods that are metabolically inactive and thus do not produce propionic, lactic, or succinic acids as their major acid products. As a result, this genus was, and is, incredibly phylogenetically diverse. Many Eubacterium species have subsequently been reassigned to other previously described, as well as novel, genera. Alternatively named members of the genus Eubacterium are therefore now widely distributed among many orders within the phylum Bacillota. Eubacterium sensu stricto is restricted to Eubacterium limosum, Eubacterium callanderi, and Eubacterium barkeri. The family Eubacteriaceae includes two additional genera from which human isolates have been described. Both Anaerofustis stercorihominis and Pseudoramibacter alactolyticus were reclassified from Eubacterium and are the sole species within their respective genera that have been isolated from humans (34). Both are rod-shaped bacteria, but the latter is arranged as pairs or clumps. Many Eubacterium species are closely related to clostridia. Importantly, phylogenetic analyses have revealed that the use of spore formation as a criterion for assignment to the genus Clostridium may be inaccurate. For example, Eubacterium siraeum is most closely related to Clostridium leptum and Anaerotruncus colihominis (35). The bacterium Catabacter hongkongensis, in the family Christensenellaceae, has been taxonomically reclassified as Christensenella hongkongensis which is a nonhemolytic, catalase-positive, motile, strictly anaerobic, catalase-positive Gram-positive coccobacillus (36). The genus also includes two newly described species that stain Gram negative: Christensenella intestinihominis, which is a short, straight rod (37), and Christensenella minuta, which is a rod with tapered ends (38).

The familyLachnospiraceae includes several genera that were previously considered part of the genus Eubacterium. To date, 17 distinct genera in this family have been isolated from humans. This includes several newly described genera, as well as several previously unassigned genera whose taxonomy was recently illuminated using WGS. Anaerobutyricum is a Gram-positive rod isolated from an infant’s feces (39). Members of the genus Anaerostipes are Gram-positive bacilli that may be arranged in short chains, with Anaerostipes hadrus so named because of its relatively large cells, ~3 by 0.5 μm (40). Notably, Anaerostipes rhamnosivorans and Anaerostipes butyraticus are spore forming, whereas Anaerostipes hadrus and Anaerostipes caccae are not (41, 42). The previously unassigned genus Blautia, several species of which were formerly members of the genus Ruminococcus, has now been revealed to be a member of the family Lachnospiraceae (43). These Gram-positive coccobacilli can appear oval with pointed ends. Consistent with the inclusion of some Clostridium species in this genus, some isolates can produce spores. The newly described Butyribacter intestini strains are Gram negative and were isolated from human stool (44).

Originally believed to be aBacteroides species, Catonella morbi are pleomorphic, nonmotile Gram-negative or -variable coccobacilli arranged in short pairs and chains. Central swelling may be observed when the cells are grown in medium with fermentable carbohydrates (45). Dorea was separated from Eubacterium as its own genus in 2002 and includes nonmotile, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods (46). Eisenbergiella tayi was first described as a novel species in 2014, being most closely related to “Clostridium/Clostridioides group” on the basis of 16S rRNA gene sequence (47). E. tayi is a nonmotile, non-spore-forming bacillus that is structurally Gram positive but frequently stains Gram negative (48). Cells may be wavy and medium, long, or filamentous with tapered ends (47).

Faecalimonas umbilicata is a Gram-positive coccobacillus that can occur in pairs or short chains (49), whereas Fusicatenibacter saccharivorans is a long (up to 15 μm), spindle-shaped Gram-positive rod arranged in pairs and short chains (50). Lachnoanaerobaculum organisms are easily decolorized Gram-positive, spore-forming rods that are curved and filamentous with swellings (51). The genus Lachnospira is composed of three species, Lachnospira multipara, Lachnospira pectinoschiza, and Lachnospira eligens. Whereas Lachnospira multipara is a weakly Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, monotrichous, curved or helicoidal bacillus up to 4 μm long with bluntly pointed ends, Lachnospira pectinoschiza is a Gram-positive peritrichous bacillus that can form spore-like structures upon prolonged incubation (52). L. eligens was previously assigned as Eubacterium eligens and is a straight to slightly curved rod occurring singly, in pairs, or in short chains (53). Marvinbryantia was renamed from Bryantella and Marvinbryantia formatexigens is the only species. M. formatexigens cells are non-spore-forming, Gram-positive nonmotile, short rods in pairs and short chains (54). Merdimonas is a novel genus of rod-shaped bacteria with rounded ends (55). Moryella indologenes, the only species in its genus, is a nonmotile, Gram-variable, non-spore-forming rod with pointed ends, typically arranged singly, in pairs, or in short chains (56).

Oribacterium (Oribacterium sinus is the type species) was named in 2004 (57) with Oribacterium asaccharolyticum and Oribacterium parvus added in 2014 (58). These are structurally Gram positive but may stain Gram negative and appear as elongated, ovoid, non-spore-forming rods arranged singly, in pairs, or in short chains and motile by means of laterally inserted flagella. Robinsoniella peoriensis is a Gram-positive ovoid to short bacillus arranged in single cells or in pairs. Spores form subterminally without causing cell swelling. Roseburia cecicola was the first-described species in the genus, which was later augmented with R. intestinalis in 2002 and then R. faecis, R. hominis, and R. inulinivorans in 2006 (59), with Roseburia amylophila more recently added. Roseburia spp. are slightly curved bacilli that stain Gram variable or Gram negative. They are motile by means of multiple subterminal flagella. Shuttleworthia, with Shuttleworthia satelles as the sole member identified to date, are non-spore-forming, nonmotile, Gram-positive, short and variably curved bacilli occurring singly, in pairs or short chains, or in a diphtheroidal arrangement (60). Stomatobaculum longum was proposed as a novel species in 2013, with M. indologenes being the closest taxonomic relative, based on the 16S rRNA gene locus. S. longum are nonmotile, non-spore-forming, Gram-variable rods up to 40 μm long, commonly with swellings and occurring singly or in chains; they can form curved filamentous forms up to 200 μm long (36).

The familiesPeptostreptococcaceae and Ruminococcaceae (now Oscillospiraceae), despite their names, harbor members that are anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods, many of which have their closest relatives among the clostridia. Ruminococcaceae was recently deemed by taxonomists to be an illegitimate name and has now been renamed with the earlier, validly published name Oscillospiraceae (61). Since the last edition of this Manual, there have been substantial numbers of novel genera described in this family that have been isolated from humans. The genus Anaerotruncus, with its sole validly published member being the species A. colihominis, is a thin rod-shaped bacillus (35). Dysosmobacter welbionis and Faecalibacterium species are rods that stain Gram negative (37, 62). Eubacterium plautii, along with Clostridium orbiscindens, was reclassified to the species Flavonifractor plautii (63); F. plautii appears as Gram-variable rods that may or may not produce spores and harbors the sporulation gene spoA. In contrast, Pseudoflavonifractor organisms are straight or curved rods that do not sporulate despite having the spoA gene. Intestinimonas massiliensis (64), Lawsonibacter asaccharolyticus (65), and Mageeibacillus indolicus stain Gram negative, with the latter having blunt or tapered ends (66). Massiliimalia species are small rods that can stain Gram positive or Gram negative depending on the species (67). Ruthenibacterium lactatiformans organisms are rods that stain Gram negative and occur singly or in pairs, with occasional coccoid cells observed attached to the cell poles (68). Solibaculum mannosilyticum is a Gram-variable rod (69). Subdoligranulum variabile (70, 71) stains Gram negative and has a highly variable morphology ranging from coccoid to droplet shaped. Last, Filifactor alocis and Filifactor villosus are related to Eubacterium yurii and are members of the family Peptostreptococcaceae (72). Spore production can occasionally be observed with this genus. The genus Mogibacterium (tentatively assigned to its own family, Mogibacteriaceae) is composed of six asaccharolytic species, which are short Gram-positive rods that are closely related to E. infirmum (28).

sect2.title: Class Erysipelotrichia
sect2.para: Several anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods have been described that are phylogenetically more closely related toErysipelothrix rhusiopathiae than other genera. Within the family Erysipelotrichaceae, Amedibacterium intestinale organisms stain Gram positive and are straight rods or coccobacilli, while Amedibacillus dolichus (formerly Eubacterium dolichum) organisms are straight rods that occur in long chains (73). Bulleidia extructa organisms are short bacilli that appear singly or in pairs aligned side by side (74). Faecalibacillus species are long (3.5 to 4.5 μm) Gram-positive rods (75). Faecalitalea cylindroides are pleomorphic Gram-positive rods occurring singly, in pairs, or in short chains (76). Holdemania filiformis and H. massiliensis occur in pairs and short chains (77), and Solobacterium moorei organisms typically appear as small rods that tend to occur singly (78).

Catenibacterium mitsuokai (79), in the family Coprobacillaceae, which was described following its isolation from the stool of Papua New Guinea highlanders, is a Gram-positive rod occurring in tangled chains. Coprobacillus cateniformis appears as coccobacilli that occur in chains and phenotypically resemble Collinsella species (80). Eggerthia catenaformis (formerly Lactobacillus catenaformis) appears as rods occurring in short chains (81). Finally, Turicibacter sanguinis is the sole species in the family Turicibacteraceae isolated from humans and is a long and irregular-shaped rod that forms long chains up to 30 μm long (82).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Most Gram-positive anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods are members of the commensal microbiota found on and within the mucocutaneous surfaces of the human body (i.e., orogastrointestinal and urogenital tracts as well as the skin). While certain bacteria within this group are associated with a healthy microbiome, dysbiosis (i.e., imbalance) of this microbiome can be associated with the presence of a disease state (e.g., bacterial vaginosis [BV]). The roles that individual bacterial species play in promoting dysbiosis and disease states are only beginning to be elucidated. Where members of this group cause infections, the host itself is the most likely source. Infections with the commensal microbiotas of others can occur in the case of infections resulting from bite wounds (human or animal) or clenched-fist injuries from striking the face and mouth (83).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Infections with non-spore-forming, anaerobic, Gram-positive rods can occur when these bacteria gain access to privileged sites. These bacteria seldom cause infections alone and are instead usually involved in polymicrobial infections associated with mucosal surfaces (Table 1). Many anaerobes involved in infections of the head and neck originate from the oral cavity, whereas most vaginal and bladder infections with these bacteria are of fecal origin. With intra-abdominal infections due to organ perforation, the organisms present depend on the microbiota present at the site of leakage. For surgical patients, anaerobes are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. Anaerobic bacteria can occasionally spread to adjacent tissues and the bloodstream, with serious consequences, with anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods accounting for up to one-quarter of bacteremia due to anaerobes (84). For anaerobic bacteremia, the gastrointestinal tract (GI) is the most common source, followed by abscesses, gynecologic infections, and wound infections. The incidence and range of anaerobic, Gram-positive rods found in blood cultures may be underestimated, because many of these bacteria are slow growing and have fastidious nutritional requirements in contrast to Clostridium species and Bacteroides fragilis, which grow readily and rapidly in commonly used broth media (85).

sect3.title: Actinomyces and Alternatively Named Actinomyces Genus Members
sect3.para: Actinomyces and reclassified Actinomyces members (now of the genera Bowdenia, Pauljensenia, Winkia, Gleimia, and Schaalia) are normal inhabitants of mucosal surfaces throughout the human body (86). However, infection can result when these bacteria are introduced into deeper tissues because of trauma or surgery or when the mucosal surface is damaged by the presence of foreign material. Actinomycosis is a granulomatous disease that occurs more frequently in adult patients, though it can also be found in children (87). It is often associated with the presence of sinus tracts and is typically diagnosed based on clinical and histopathologic evaluation. Actinomycosis is classically associated with the presence of sulfur granules, though sulfur granules may not always be present in pus. When visualized microscopically, sulfur granules have characteristic aggregates of branching Gram-positive rods, surrounded predominantly by polymorphonuclear cells (88). Nevertheless, actinomycosis is almost universally polymicrobial in nature: 94.5% of cases of cervicofacial actinomycosis had other bacteria coisolated, with 47.6% of cases having both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria coisolated (89). It is estimated that 75 to 95% of actinomycosis cases overall have other bacteria present, with Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans and anginosus group streptococci being commonly coisolated in addition to other aerobes and/or anaerobes (90).

Actinomycosis is commonly categorized into orocervicofacial, thoracic, and abdominopelvic forms. Orocervical is the most common form of actinomycosis and accounts for over 50% of all actinomycosis cases. Poor dentition and oral hygiene are risk factors for infection, which can occur secondary to untreated dental caries, dental extraction, or trauma. The hard palate is an uncommon site for actinomycosis. Bisphosphate-related osteonecrosis of the jaw associated with these organisms has been reported, which can be observed among oncology patients (91). Thoracic actinomycosis is believed to occur secondary to aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions, though it can also result from either hematogenous or direct spread from other local sites. The diagnosis of thoracic actinomycosis is frequently delayed on account of its nonspecific initial clinical presentation. One study reported that one-third of thoracic actinomycosis cases were initially misdiagnosed as malignancy (92). In addition to lung cancer, the differential diagnosis for thoracic actinomycosis includes pneumonia and tuberculosis. The disease can progress to empyema necessitatis, wherein abscess formation occurs on the thoracic wall with subsequent erosion and invasion of the surrounding bone structures (93). The majority of pelvic infections are found in women using intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUDs) (94). Abdominal infection most commonly arises following perforation of the bowel as a result of disease or surgery (95).
