b+, positive; (+), decolorization in old culture; −, negative; v, variable.

Among the current and alternatively named members of the genusActinomyces, Actinomyces israelii, A. gerencseriae, A. graevenitzii, and A. propionica are believed to be most associated with classic actinomycosis (86, 88). It is important to note that these bacteria can also cause actinomycosis beyond just classical actinomycosis; cutaneous, musculoskeletal, pericarditis, and central nervous system (CNS) infections, as well as disseminated disease, have all been previously observed. Keratitis, endophthalmitis, and canaliculitis due to these bacteria have also been described. The importance of current and alternatively named members of Actinomyces as agents of granulomatous breast infections is an emerging clinical entity (96). A variety of species are associated with breast abscesses and, when isolated, more frequently occur as constituents of a polymicrobial culture (97). These bacteria are also associated with a variety of dental and oral infections, including dental caries, endodontic infections, odontogenic abscesses, and dental implant-associated infections (98–101). Oral Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces species can be detected in the bloodstream following dental procedures (102). These bacteria can also be frequently isolated from sputum samples of adult cystic fibrosis patients when anaerobic culture methods are used, though the clinical significance of this finding is unclear (103). Finally, these organisms are causes of genitourinary infections (104).

The species most frequently isolated from clinical infections within this group areSchaalia turicensis, Schaalia radingae, and W. neuii and are found in a range of soft tissue infections including perianal, groin, axillary, breast, and periauricular abscesses (86, 105). Gleimia europaea, Schaalia funkei, Schaalia georgiae, and A. timonensis are also isolated from similar soft tissue infections. In addition, A. naeslundii and A. israelii have been isolated from infected hip prostheses (106). Several Actinomyces species (and alternatively named species), including Schaalia cardiffensis, A. gerencseriae, A. naeslundii, Schaalia odontolytica, and A. urogenitalis, have been associated with infections of IUDs, though A. israelii and S. turicensis are most commonly implicated (6, 107–109). Schaalia meyeri has been shown to have a predilection for causing pulmonary actinomycosis, and dissemination to other organs has been observed (92). Pericarditis caused by A. israelii and S. meyeri has been reported (110). Due to the small numbers of human clinical isolates reported to date, the natural habitats, and clinical associations of A. dentalis, Gleimia hominis, P. hongkongensis, B. nasicola, A. oricola, and A. radicidentis have yet to be fully determined.

One major caveat in our understanding of the epidemiology of actinomycosis is that the majority of published studies did not use molecular methods for species identification (89). Thus, described species-level disease associations should be interpreted cautiously. In one study in which all Actinomyces strains isolated from invasive specimens were subjected to 16S rRNA gene sequencing, the following observations were made (111). A. graevenitzii was recovered only from lung fluids or tissues and not from any other source. All S. radingae strains were isolated from skin and soft tissue infections of the thoracic region, and the majority of W. neuii strains from skin and soft tissue abscesses, the latter finding having been confirmed independently (112). W. neuii has also been associated with a wide variety of infections, including late periprosthetic joint infection of the shoulder (113), bacteremia, and postoperative endophthalmitis (112). Most bloodstream infections were due to S. odontolytica. A. israelii and S. meyeri were isolated from CNS infections (e.g., brain abscesses). With the application of 16S rRNA gene PCR followed by NGS to brain abscess specimens, Actinomyces and alternatively named members of the genus were commonly detected (most frequently S. meyeri) (114). However, the clinical significance of this molecular detection is not entirely clear, as many of these patients did not have the organism isolated in culture, and were therefore not specifically treated for Actinomyces, yet had favorable outcomes. It is apparent that additional species of this group of bacteria remain to be described, with 18% of isolates from pulmonary fluids and blood cultures being undescribed species (111).

sect3.title: Actinobaculum and Actinotignum
sect3.para: Actinotignum schaalii is the species most frequently implicated in human disease among the genera Actinotignum and Actinobaculum. Bacteremia, endocarditis, Fournier’s gangrene, abscesses, cellulitis, discitis, and spondylodiscitis have also been reported (115–117). Most reported infections involve the urinary tract, with infections most commonly encountered in the elderly. However, some evidence suggests that this bacterium may also cause urinary tract infection (UTI) among pediatric patients (118). A. schaalii also appears to be a member of the urinary microbiota, which can complicate interpretation of its significance when isolated from urine culture (119). These bacteria have also been detected from swabs of the genitourinary area but not fecal swabs (120). Importantly, the true prevalence of urinary tract infection due to this group of bacteria is likely to be underestimated, as isolation in vitro requires incubation for at least 48 h in the presence of CO2, neither of which conditions are not routinely employed by most clinical laboratories performing urine cultures.

Physicians may not be familiar with the clinical significance of these organisms and thus may not consider their isolation in blood culture significant (121). An additional issue hindering recognition of these organisms as agents of infection is that phenotypic identification systems have traditionally been unable to accurately identify these organisms. A. schaalii bacteremia is associated with a mortality rate of 16%, with over 50% of patients experiencing severe sepsis. However, this finding may be due to the advanced age and comorbidities among many of the patients who develop infection with this bacterium (122). A. massiliense is associated with soft tissue abscesses, with a single case report of pelvic inflammatory disease reported (123). Actinotignum urinale has been isolated from a patient with chronic renal failure (124), and cases of A. urinale and A. sanguinis bacteremia have been reported (122).

sect3.title: Mobiluncus
sect3.para: The Gram-variable, curved Gram-positive rods of the genusMobiluncus can be detected in samples from the female vaginal tract. M. curtisii is more readily detected in vaginal samples from women with BV, although molecular methods can also detect its presence among women without the disease (125). Up to 82% of neovaginal samples from transgender patients tested were positive for M. curtisii by PCR in one study (126). There is some evidence that M. curtisii isolates recovered from the cervix may differ from strains isolated from the vagina with respect to their inflammatory potential. M. curtisii has been isolated from patients with breast abscesses and bacteremia (5, 127), though emerging data suggest that when bacteremia occurs, gastrointestinal symptoms are also present (e.g., diarrhea, abdominal pain, etc.) (128). M. curtisii has also been postulated to play a role in spontaneous preterm delivery (129). M. mulieris, cells of which typically appear to be longer than those of M. curtisii, is readily detected from the vaginal tracts of women without BV. Extragenital infections with M. mulieris have also been described, with published reports of hepatic and intra-abdominal abscesses (130). M. holmesii has been isolated from the vaginal tracts of women with and without BV and has also been isolated from breast abscesses (131).

sect3.title: Varibaculum
sect3.para: Though the natural habitat ofVaribaculum cambriense is unknown, this organism has been isolated from a wide variety of sources, including IUD-associated infections as well as cerebral, postauricular, submandibular, and breast abscesses (6, 132). V. cambriense was also noted to be capable of causing skin and soft tissue infections, with abscesses within the groin region predominantly noted. Varibaculum anthropi has been isolated from urine, sinuses, and vaginal tracts as well as from abscesses (7). The recently described Varibaculum vaginae and Varibaculum timonense were isolated from the vagina and stool, respectively, of two different healthy women (9). Varibaculum massiliense is a slow-growing bacterium that was isolated from the urine of a man on chronic hemodialysis after 7 days of anaerobic incubation (8). Members of this genus were identified by phenotypic identification or matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) and thus required 16S rRNA gene sequencing (133).

sect3.title: Cutibacterium and Related Genera
sect3.para: The cutaneous group of propionibacteria, now reclassified asCutibacterium species, are members of the skin microbiota. However, these organisms can also be detected within the GI and genitourinary tracts as well as from the oral cavity (134, 135) and in about 20% of infected dog and cat bite wounds (136). Cutibacterium acnes can also be detected in the sputum of adult cystic fibrosis patients, though the clinical significance of this finding is unknown (103). While these bacteria are frequently dismissed as contaminants by clinical laboratories, appreciation for their role as agents of infection has increased in recent years (137). In particular, the ability of C. acnes to form biofilms on the surface of foreign material within the body has been extensively described. C. acnes has emerged as an important cause of neurosurgical shunt infections as well as an agent of infections associated with breast implants, intraocular lenses (keratitis), and cardiac devices (i.e., prosthetic-valve endocarditis and implantable cardioverter defibrillator [ICD] and pacemaker infections) (138–141). One-third of C. acnes endocarditis cases are complicated by intracardiac abscess formation, potentially as a result of delayed treatment due to the initial isolation of C. acnes being deemed insignificant (142). Cases of native-valve endocarditis caused by C. acnes have also been reported (143). Some studies have also suggested a possible role for C. acnes in disk degeneration in the absence of hardware as well as in prostate cancer and sarcoidosis, though these are controversial (144). C. acnes has also been associated with a variety of infections that do not involve foreign material, including delayed surgical site infection after hepatic surgery (145), intraperitoneal abscess after a hysterectomy (146), brain abscesses (147), and pericarditis (148).

Arguably, it is the role ofC. acnes as a causative agent of periprosthetic joint infection (PJI) that has garnered the most attention. These infections typically have a delayed onset (i.e., >3 months after arthroplasty) and are indolent in presentation, with pain often being the only presenting symptom (149). C. acnes colonizes the sebaceous glands and hair follicles, with a predilection for the upper body, and thus infections are observed more frequently in shoulders than in hips and knees (135). Infections occur more commonly among men, who tend to have higher organism burdens (150, 151). Interpretation of the significance of isolation of this bacterium from patients undergoing revision shoulder arthroplasty is complicated by the fact that this organism can be readily isolated from the surgical incisions of patients undergoing shoulder arthroplasty or revision arthroplasty procedures (152), including from patients who had received antimicrobial surgical prophylaxis (153). Interestingly, isolates of C. acnes from deep sites differ from those isolated more superficially in terms of biofilm production abilities and appear to belong to different phylotypes and possibly even subspecies (154). There has been some suggestion that the visualization of beta-hemolysis on sheep blood agar can distinguish deep isolates from those present due to contamination, though this has not been confirmed (155). There is also a growing body of evidence to suggest that C. acnes may play a role in nonunion fracture fixations (156), which appears to be supported by animal model data (157).

OtherCutibacterium species have also been reported to be associated with PJI. Although C. acnes only rarely causes PJI of the hips and knees (158), a cluster of PJIs caused by Cutibacterium avidum predominantly from prosthetic hips and knees has been reported (159). The C. avidum strains associated with infection were noted to be beta-hemolytic. Prosthetic-valve endocarditis caused by C. avidum has been reported, though it is far less commonly encountered than C. acnes in this setting (160). C. avidum has also been isolated from patients with prosthetic-valve endocarditis, as well as breast, abdominal, splenic, and perianal abscesses and osteomyelitis (161–164). Cutibacterium granulosum has been isolated from patients with PJI, endocarditis, uveitis, and postoperative endophthalmitis (165–167). C. modestum (formerly “C. humerusii”) has been isolated from patients with PJI of the shoulder as well as in native vertebral osteomyelitis (168). This bacterium is misidentified as C. acnes if only spot tests are performed (i.e., catalase and indole), though it can be distinguished from C. acnes by 16S rRNA gene sequencing (12). Cutibacterium namnetense is a relatively newly described species that has been isolated from bone specimens with a single case report of liver abscess after transarterial chemoembolization in a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma (169).

P. lymphophilum appears to be associated with urinary tract infections, with two cases reported among elderly male patients with >105 CFU/ml isolated after prolonged anaerobic incubation (72 h) (170). Metagenomic studies support a urinary source for this bacterium, and both polymicrobial bacteremia (coisolation with A. schaalii) and monomicrobial bacteremia cases have been reported (171, 172). This bacterium is positive for nitrites but can be negative for nitrate reduction with identification systems. P. innocua is part of the skin microbiota (173), with no human infections reported to date. A. propionica (formerly Pseudopropionibacterium propionicum) is associated with actinomycosis and has also been reported to cause both oral and eye infections (101, 174, 175). Propionibacterium acidifaciens has been isolated from the human oral cavity, and microbiome studies suggest a potential role in dental caries (176). The closely related novel genera Enemella and Parenemella have been isolated from a variety of clinical specimens, including cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and blood, as well as from lung and lymph node biopsy specimens (15). In contrast, Vaginimicrobium has been isolated only from the vagina of a woman without BV, with no infections reported to date (16).

sect3.title: Bifidobacterium and Related Bacteria
sect3.para: Bifidobacterium species are members of the human orogastrointestinal and vaginal microbiota. These bacteria constitute >80% of the intestinal microbiota of breast-fed infants compared with <6% of intestinal microbiota among adults (177). Bifidobacterium (predominantly Bifidobacterium dentium) have been known to be associated with dental caries for some time (178, 179). Bacteremia has been reported among patients at the extremes of age (i.e., the elderly and neonates) and is frequently polymicrobial (177). Bifidobacterium species used as a probiotic reduces the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis among extremely premature infants and decreases all-cause mortality in this group (180). However, bacteremia has been reported with strains shown by WGS to be genetically identical to those used in the probiotic formulation received by these patients (181). The frequency with which this occurs may be underestimated, because anaerobic blood cultures are not typically performed in this patient population. Similarly, infections secondary to probiotic administration have been reported among hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients (182). Most reported cases of bacteremia have involved Bifidobacterium longum, and peritonitis, otitis media, pericarditis, pneumonia, and abdominal abscesses associated with this species have also been reported (110, 183, 184). Cases of Bifidobacterium breve associated with bacteremia, ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt infection, peritonsillar abscess, and peritonitis have been reported (185, 186). Recurrent UTIs have been reported for Bifidobacterium scardovii, along with isolation of this bacterium from both blood and hip specimens (187). B. scardovii may occasionally appear as weakly hemolytic as well as curved.

The clinical significance ofAlloscardovia isolation in culture is not always clear, though Alloscardovia omnicolens appears to have a predilection for the urinary tract (188). This occurs predominantly among female patients, where quantities exceeding 105 CFU/ml can be recovered (189). Though this alpha-hemolytic bacterium can grow aerobically in CO2, the incidence of infection may have been overlooked prior to the availability of MALDI-TOF MS as it is not readily identified using phenotypic identification systems. A. omnicolens has also been isolated from other sites including blood, saliva, lung, and peritonsillar and aortic valve abscesses (188). One study suggested a potential association with premature rupture of membranes in a pregnant patient, but whether such an association is borne out in additional studies remains to be seen (190). Parascardovia denticolens, Scardovia inopinata, and Scardovia wiggsiae have been implicated in dental caries (175, 178, 179, 191, 192). In addition, S. wiggsiae has also been isolated from a wound culture from an injection drug user (191).

sect3.title: Collinsella
sect3.para: Collinsella species have been isolated from both feces as well as the oral cavity of humans (23, 78). Infections caused by this bacterium are not widely reported, though our institution had a patient with polymicrobial bacteremia with this bacterium that was correctly identified by Vitek ANC card, Bruker MALDI Biotyper, and Vitek MS (S. Butler-Wu, unpublished data). The recently described Collinsella vaginalis was isolated from a woman with BV (190).

sect3.title: Atopobium, Lancefieldella and Fannyhessea
sect3.para: As discussed above,A. parvulum, A. rimae, and A. vaginae having been reclassified as L. rimae, L. parvula, and F. vaginae, respectively. These bacteria are slow-growing anaerobes some of which are associated with dental infections such as endodontic abscess and periodontitis (e.g., L. parvula and L. rimae) (193), though other studies have suggested a potential beneficial role for these bacteria in oral health (194). Members of this group can also be detected from feces using molecular methods. L. rimae and Atopobium deltae have been associated with bacteremia (195, 196), with the latter occurring in a patient with Fournier’s gangrene. F. vaginae appears to play an important role in BV (197) and is associated with Gardnerella vaginalis biofilms (198–200). As with Mobiluncus, F. vaginae is frequently detected among patients with BV as well as in the neovaginas of transgender female patients (126), though this bacterium may also be detected in patients without BV (201). F. vaginae bacteremia has been reported to occur both intrapartum (202) and in a patient with a tubo-ovarian abscess who suffered fetal loss (203). The majority of bacteremia cases have occurred in pregnant women (204), and a case of endocarditis caused by F. vaginae has now also been reported (205). There are some data suggesting that F. vaginae may be associated with pelvic inflammatory disease, as well as increased risk of persistent endometritis and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, though these associations are controversial (206). These issues are thought in part to be the result of dysbiosis. Evidence suggests that high levels of this bacterium (F. vaginae DNA at concentrations >108 copies/ml) are associated with preterm birth (207). Atopobium minutum has been isolated from various infections of the lower part of the body, and L. parvula has been isolated from respiratory specimens. Rare instances of high-level vancomycin resistance due to vanB gene carriage has been described in A. minutum (208).

sect3.title: Olsenella
sect3.para: FiveOlsenella species have been isolated from humans to date. Both O. profusa and O. uli have been associated with dental caries and can found in subgingival sites in periodontitis patients (209–211). O. uli has also been isolated from a patient with bacteremia with acute cholangitis (212) and in a case of chronic endophthalmitis with Leuconostoc species (213). The newly described species O. massiliensis, O. phocaeensis, and O. urininfantis have been isolated from human urine and/or feces (21, 214). In addition, members of the two novel genera within the family Atopobiaceae named Thermophilibacter and Parolsenella have been isolated from intestinal and fecal samples, respectively, with no human infections yet reported.

sect3.title: Eggerthella and Paraeggerthella
sect3.para: Members of theEggerthella genus are inhabitants of the human intestine. A wide array of human infections have been attributed to this genus, including spondylodiscitis, peritonitis, and brain, liver, and pyogenic liver abscesses, as well as necrotizing pneumonia and osteomyelitis (215–217). Though E. lenta (formerly Eubacterium lentum) bacteremia has been well characterized (218, 219), studies have revealed that up to 50% of cases of bacteremia previously attributed to “E. lenta” were in fact due to E. sinensis and Paraeggerthella hongkongensis (220). In one recent analysis, Eggerthella species accounted for 71% of bacteremia caused by anaerobic non-spore-forming rods (221). Mortality with these bacteria ranges between 20 and 40% for patients with bacteremia, with more than 40% of cases noted to be polymicrobial (222). Immunosuppression is an important risk factor for the development of bacteremia with these organisms. Some studies have described an association between bacteremia and cancer leading to translocation from the gastrointestinal tract (222). Whether isolation of Eggerthella or Paraeggerthella from blood culture should prompt additional diagnostic imaging of the abdomen remains to be determined (212, 220). An as-yet-unnamed, Eggerthella-like taxon appears to be associated with BV (223).

sect3.title: Slackia and other Eggerthellaceae
sect3.para: Six recognized members of the genusSlackia have been described, though only three have been isolated from humans. Slackia equolifaciens and Slackia piriformis appear to be found in the human intestine. One study also suggested that Eggerthella may be more associated with the intestinal wall, whereas Slackia appears to be more luminal (224). Slackia exigua is responsible for most reported infections with this bacterium. S. exigua is associated with chronic periodontitis (194, 225) and is also a rare cause of pyogenic infections outside the oral cavity, with reports of empyema, polymicrobial abscesses (breast, peritonsillar, lung and intestinal) (226–228), and periprosthetic joint infection (229). Polymicrobial bacteremia secondary to a periapical abscess and feculent meningitis have also been noted for this organism (230), though monomicrobial bacteremia due to this bacterium was recently reported (231).

Cryptobacterium curtum, the sole member of the genus Cryptobacterium, appears to be associated with dental abscesses, chronic periodontitis, and endodontic infections (194, 225, 232). Species of Enterorhabdus, members of which have now been taxonomically reclassified as Adlercreutzia, are believed to be members of the intestinal microbiota, with Adlercreutzia equolifaciens having been isolated from human feces (27); no human infections with these bacteria have been described to date. Gordonibacter faecihominis and Gordonibacter urolithinfaciens have both been isolated from human feces (30), and the catalase-positive Gordonibacter pamelaeae was isolated from a patient with bacteremia (233). Ellagibacter (29), Enteroscipio, and Rubneribacter are newly described members of the family Eggerthellaceae (31). All three genera have been isolated from human stool, with no infections reported to date.

sect3.title: Lactobacillus and Alternatively Named Lactobacillus Genus Members
sect3.para: As discussed earlier, massive taxonomic reclassification has resulted in manyLactobacillus species being reclassified into several novel genera. Lactobacilli and related genera are regarded as beneficial members of the human microbiome, but they can infrequently act as opportunistic pathogens in both children and adults (134, 234). Among members of the genus Limosilactobacillus, several species have been isolated from the human stomach, including Limosilactobacillus antri and Limosilactobacillus fermentum. Patients with infection due to lactobacilli often have underlying conditions, such as malignancy, history of organ transplant, recent history of surgical procedure, or diabetes mellitus.

Lactobacillus and alternatively named Lactobacillus species most frequently isolated from invasive infections are L. rhamnosus, Lacticaseibacillus casei, L. fermentum, L. plantarum, L. acidophilus, L. salivarius, and L. paracasei. A great variety of other species have also been reported to cause infections, including L. gasseri, L. jensenii, Weissella confusa, Latilactobacillus curvatus, and Ligilactobacillus salivarius (235). Lactobacilli are particularly associated with advanced dental caries (99, 175, 236), where they are considered a secondary colonizer because of their preference for low-pH habitats but probably play a role in exacerbating existing lesions (237). The clinical infections most commonly reported to be caused by lactobacilli are bacteremia and endocarditis (both prosthetic and native valve), with L. rhamnosus and L. casei being the predominant species (212, 234, 238, 239). The oral cavity is likely a major portal of entry, either from poor dentition or following dental procedures (234). Compromise to the gastrointestinal and genitourinary mucosa may also serve as a source of bloodstream infection following surgical or other procedures (240, 241). For example, L. jensenii infections have been noted in females who have undergone procedures to the genitourinary tract (240).

Numerous other infections have been attributed to lactobacilli, including peritonitis, chorioamnionitis, and intra-abdominal abscess. Meningitis and even meningoencephalitis cases have also been described (242–244). Though rare, septic arthritis and periprosthetic joint infection do occur (244, 245). Importantly, lactobacilli are frequently isolated alongside other microorganisms, most notably Candida, Enterococcus, and Klebsiella species, and such polymicrobial infections have been associated with higher mortality (234). Clinical laboratories are likely to isolate lactobacilli with some frequency from both sterile and nonsterile specimen sources. Clinical interpretation of such cultures must consider patient history and other microbiologic findings, bearing in mind that lactobacilli can be pathogenic in the proper setting (234, 238).

Concern has been expressed that probiotic strains consumed in foodstuffs may cause disease in some individuals. Rare cases in the literature describe heavy consumption of dairy products as a possible source of infection (234). Even with the widespread usage of probiotic supplements, the actual risk of Lactobacillus infection is quite low (246). Nonetheless, probiotic strains such as L. rhamnosus GG have been reported in cases of sepsis or endocarditis in pediatric and adult patients (247–249). In some cases, inappropriate dosages and routes of administration of the probiotic supplement were reported. As a caveat, an epidemiological link cannot be assumed when infection occurs after probiotic ingestion. One study using molecular typing found that the strains of Lactobacillus from the patient’s blood culture and from the probiotic formula taken were distinct (250).

Next-generation sequencing has demonstrated that the normal vaginal microbiota is composed of a limited number of bacterial species dominated byL. crispatus or L. iners and less commonly by L. gasseri or L. jensenii. Abundant L. iners may still be found in intermediate states of bacterial vaginosis (251). Depletion of Lactobacillus from the vaginal microbiota and increased bacterial diversity are characteristic features of bacterial vaginosis and correlated with increased vaginal pH and abnormal Nugent score (252).

sect3.title: Eubacterium
sect3.para: The genusEubacterium remains poorly defined, but species belonging to this genus and its relatives can be commonly isolated from oral infections (including chronic periodontitis) (Table 1), particularly when nutrient-rich media and extended incubation times are used (253). Due to their presence in the oral cavity, various Eubacterium and related species can be isolated from human bite wound infections (136). Eubacterium nodatum has been found in infections of the female genital tract (254), while Eubacterium brachy was associated with a lung abscess in one report (255). Several Eubacterium species have been associated with clinically significant bacteremia (e.g., Eubacterium tenue and Eubacterium callanderi, with Eubacterium limosum being the most commonly encountered Eubacterium species associated with this infection) (212, 256).

sect3.title: Pseudoramibacter
sect3.para: Several novel genera have emerged from what were formerly considered members of the genusEubacterium. P. alactolyticus can be detected in the oral cavity and has been associated with a variety of oral infections, including apical periodontics, apical abscess, caries, endodontic infections, and infected root canals (77). There is a single report of P. alactolyticus and Mycobacterium tuberculosis codetection from a brain abscess (257), which to date is the only report of infection with this bacterium outside the oral cavity.

sect3.title: Christensenella and Other Eubacteriaceae
sect3.para: C. hongkongensis has been isolated from blood cultures, with 14 reported cases (258). A majority of cases reported in the literature include bacteremia and sepsis (259, 260), with high mortality rates observed (258, 261). Most patients have underlying conditions, with a suggested gastrointestinal source in many cases (e.g., bacteremia secondary to perforated appendix and intestinal perforation). This bacterium is not identified by the API 20A or rapid ANA II system. Similarly, it is not identified by MALDI-TOF MS due to the absence of spectra in commercial databases (258), but it was recently successfully identified by metagenomic sequencing performed on a positive blood culture that initially failed to grow on subculture to solid medium (262). Two other species in this genus (C. intestinihominis and C. minuta) have been isolated from human feces, though infections with these have not yet been reported (38, 263). A. stercorihominis has been isolated from human feces, but no human infections have been described to date.

sect3.title: Robinsoniella
sect3.para: R. peoriensis was originally identified in swine manure but has also been found in a deep heel wound and blood from human sources (264). It has since been identified in the fecal microbiotas of healthy premature neonates (265). Robinsoniella has been documented in a variety of human infections, including bacteremia, intra-abdominal infection, posttraumatic and postsurgical wound infections, infected prosthetic joints, endocarditis, and an infected mycotic pseudoaneurysm (266–270). Elevated MICs for penicillin and clindamycin were noted for this organism, and it was not identified by MALDI-TOF MS (271). Cross-reactivity in the Clostridioides difficile glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) antigen assay for stool has been hypothesized in one case, in which stool GDH was positive and C. difficile toxigenic culture was negative. R. peoriensis was isolated from stool and found to possess a putative gdh gene but no C. difficile toxin genes by whole-genome sequencing (272).

sect3.title: Lachnoanaerobaculum
sect3.para: Lachnoanaerobaculum spp. are believed to be members of the oral and gut microbiotas, but disease association has not been well established. They have been detected in blood and amniotic fluid samples in cases of preterm birth (273). Lachnoanaerobaculum saburreum has been isolated from dental plaque and was detected in polymicrobial endodontic infections (274). Lachnoanaerobaculum umeaense was discovered after being cultivated from the small bowel of a patient with celiac disease (51). A single case report has recorded Lachnoanaerobaculum orale as a cause of bacteremia, with increased fluoroquinolone MICs noted (275).

sect3.title: Blautia and Other Lachnospiraceae
sect3.para: While most species within the familyLachnospiraceae were detected in humans and animals during microbiome analysis, they have also occasionally been implicated in human infection. All 19 species of Blautia have been isolated from human feces, but to date, only one case of bacteremia with Blautia coccoides has been described (276). It has been suggested that this bacterium may play a protective role against mortality from graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), with higher Blautia abundance being associated with improved overall patient survival (277). Anaerostipes spp. were found to be major constituents of healthy gut microbiota (40–42, 278). A. caccae has been implicated in one case of bypass graft infection and bacteremia (279), but to date, no other infections with members of this genus have been reported. C. morbi is a component of oral microbiota and has been detected with other anaerobes in infected periodontal samples (280). There has been one case of native-valve endocarditis attributed to C. morbi (281). In the handful of reported cases of E. tayi infection, all isolates were from blood cultures, with one patient having concomitant isolation from appendiceal tissue (47, 48).

M. indologenes has been isolated from thigh, buttock, and intra-abdominal abscesses (56), as well as from a patient with bloodstream infection, where it was successfully identified by MALDI-TOF MS (282). This species has also been found in the human gut and oral cavity (283, 284). O. sinus was first isolated from maxillary sinus pus from a child as part of a polymicrobial infection (58). The genus has been noted as a microbe associated with denture malodor (285). Strains of Shuttleworthia were first isolated from the oral cavity in dental plaque and areas associated with periodontitis (60), and there is one published case of endocarditis attributed to Shuttleworthia satelles in a patient with prior gingival disease (286).

Several members of the familyLachnospiraceae have been isolated from humans but have not yet been described as being associated with infection. Marvinbryantia formatexigens and Dorea longicatena have been isolated from human feces (46). Similarly, Lachnospira species are considered normal members of the gut microbiota in humans (52, 287). Roseburia spp. have been isolated from human feces and are thought to be associated with a healthy gut microbiome because of their ability to produce butyrate (59, 287, 288). S. longum was first described as an isolate from the human mouth (36). The newly described B. intestini (44), F. umbilicata (49), F. saccharivorans (50), and Merdimonas faecis have been isolated from human stool (55). Anaerobutyricum has been isolated from an infant’s feces, with no infections reported to date (39).

sect3.title: Filifactor
sect3.para: F. villosus appears to be associated with periodontitis, infected root canals with apical abscesses, and endodontic infections (72). There is a high incidence of this bacterium in the periodontal pockets of patients with periodontitis and an absence of this bacterium among subjects that do not have this disease (289). This bacterium has also been isolated from infected cat bite wounds in humans (290). Consistent with its former classification as a member of the genus Eubacterium, this bacterium is difficult to identify; growth in vitro is stimulated by arginine. The more recently described species F. alocis (formerly Fusobacterium alocis) is also associated with an array of oral diseases, including periodontitis, endodontitis, and peri-implantitis (289), as well as brain abscesses (291) and empyema (292).

sect3.title: Flavonifractor
sect3.para: There are now several reports ofF. plautii bacteremia; a majority of these occurred in patients who were immunosuppressed. Bacteremia occurring secondary to acute cholecystitis (293) as well as in a patient with severe burns (294) has also been reported. The bacterium is identified to the genus level by the MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry (MS) (i.e., Bruker system; score = 1.8) and was noted to be both fluoroquinolone and linezolid resistant. F. plautii has also been isolated from intra-abdominal pus as well as a skin and soft tissue infection (63).

sect3.title: Faecalibacterium
sect3.para: Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, the sole member of the genus, is a member of the intestinal microbiota and accounts for 5% of the total fecal microbiota of healthy adults. This bacterium is believed to be a major producer of butyrate within the human intestine, which is thought to be important for maintaining healthy physiology of the gut (295). Dysbiosis of the intestinal microbiota is believed to be associated with decreased levels of this bacterium and in turn plays a purported role in several disorders of the intestine, including ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease (296).

sect3.title: Anaerotruncus and Other Oscillospiraceae
sect3.para: A. colihominis has been isolated from human feces (35), with one case of bacteremia being reported (297). Interestingly, even though spore formation was not originally described for A. colihominis, spore formation was subsequently observed in the report of bacteremia that was published. Other genera in the family Oscillospiraceae which have been isolated from human stool, but for which infection has not yet been described, include D. welbionis (62), I. massiliensis (64), L. asaccharolyticus (65), Massiliimalia species (67), Pseudoflavonifractor, R. lactatiformans (68). S. mannosilyticum (69), and S. variabile (37). Both Anaerotruncus and Subdoligranulum can stain Gram negative, though both have Gram-positive cell walls and thus are vancomycin susceptible and colistin resistant. M. indolicus, which produces indole, has been isolated from the female genital tract, but no infections with this bacterium have been reported to date (66).

sect3.title: Mogibacterium
sect3.para: The six species of the genusMogibacterium have been isolated from patients with periodontal disease, as well as from infected root canals and tongue plaque (194, 298). Infection beyond the oral cavity has not been described with this genus, though DNA from these organisms can be also detected in human feces (210). Microbiome analyses showed increased levels of Mogibacterium in patients with appendicitis compared with those in a normal appendix (299).

sect3.title: Bulleidia
sect3.para: B. extructa is the sole member of the genus Bulleidia. This bacterium is associated with periodontitis and abscesses, including dental, lung, and brain abscesses (232). B. extructa can also be found in the intestinal tract (300), with microbiome analyses showing increased levels of Bulleidia species in patients with appendicitis compared with those in the normal appendix (299). It is a very slowly growing bacterium, requiring 7 days for visible growth on agar. Interestingly, B. extructa was isolated from a patient with a periprosthetic hip infection whose arthroplasty had been performed 26 years prior (301), as well as from synovial fluid of a patient whose symptoms had begun 10 days after a dental procedure (302).

sect3.title: Solobacterium
sect3.para: Initial isolations ofS. moorei were from fecal specimens, though it is now evident that this bacterium is also associated with oral infections such endodontic abscesses, as well as halitosis. Bloodstream infection is the most commonly reported infection caused by S. moorei, generally occurring in patients with underlying conditions and malignancy (303). Both oral and intestinal sources can give rise to bloodstream infection with S. moorei, and a report of bacteremia associated with cholangitis was recently published (304). Infected pilonidal cysts, perirectal and postsurgical subcutaneous abscesses (305), and a variety of skin and soft tissue infections have been reported. Several reports of osteoarticular infections have been published, in most cases resulting from extension of a proximal skin and soft tissue infection. Two reports of intracranial abscesses, as well as a single case of necrotizing pancreatitis, have been reported (306). Commercially available phenotypic identification systems do not appear to be able to identify S. moorei, though it was identified by MALDI-TOF MS (Bruker system; score = 2.3) (307).

sect3.title: Eggerthia
sect3.para: Eggerthia catenaformis, previously classified as a member of the genus Lactobacillus, is the sole member of the genus. Individual case reports of bacteremia associated with dental abscesses (either alone or in conjunction with anginosus group streptococci) (308) and intestinal and pleural empyema and abscesses have been reported (309). More recently, this bacterium caused peritonitis in a patient on peritoneal dialysis (310), deep neck space infection (311), and septic arthritis occurring several weeks after primary anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (312). This organism can be isolated from saliva and is correctly identified by the Bruker Biotyper and Vitek MS MALDI-TOF MS systems (308, 312). E. catenaformis was reported to be susceptible to beta-lactams, clindamycin, tigecycline, and vancomycin.

sect3.title: Coprobacillus and Other Erysipelotrichaceae/Coprobacillaceae
sect3.para: C. catenaformis has been isolated from feces, and a single case of bacteremia has been reported (80, 313). The patient had undergone several rounds of chemotherapy for non-small-cell lung cancer with multiple metastases. This organism was not identified by MALDI-TOF MS (Vitek MS), requiring 16S rRNA gene sequencing for identification. C. mitsuokai appears to be part of the fecal microbiota and is the sole member of the genus Catenibacterium (79); no human infections with this bacterium have been reported. T. sanguinis was isolated from the blood culture of a patient with acute appendicitis (82) as well as from human feces (314). Other members of the family Erysipelotrichaceae that have been isolated from humans include A. intestinale, A. dolichus (73), Faecalibacillus species (75), F. cylindroides, and Holdemania species (315, 316). These bacteria have been isolated from human stool, with no infections reported to date.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Many of the bacteria described in this chapter are part of the human commensal microbiota and thus cause disease as opportunistic pathogens. The collection of specimens when a mucocutaneous site is involved can be challenging, and efforts should be made to limit contamination with the microbiota present in the vicinity of the infection. Principles of specimen acceptability and transport that apply to anaerobes also apply to this group of bacteria and should be followed accordingly (seechapter 19).

In the case of suspected periprosthetic joint infection, synovial fluid, periprosthetic tissue samples as well as the prosthesis/hardware itself may be cultured; cultures should be performed aerobically and anaerobically. The American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons (AAOS) guidelines recommends attempting culture of synovial fluid in advance of revision surgery. If periprosthetic specimens are ultimately required, the AAOS guidelines recommend that multiple periprosthetic samples be obtained (https://www.aaos.org/pjiguideline).

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: Microscopic examination has traditionally played a key role in confirming the diagnosis of actinomycosis. The macroscopic presence of sulfur granules in pus, which when crushed, Gram stained, and viewed under the microscope reveal a mass of Gram-positive, branching filaments, is pathognomonic for this infection. However, not all cases of actinomycosis have sulfur granules present. In cervical smears of samples from women with an IUD, the presence of branching, Gram-positive organisms could be suggestive of an infection withActinomyces-like bacteria (317), though studies have demonstrated the visualization of Actinomyces-like bacteria in Pap smears from asymptomatic women with IUDs (318). Gram stains of vaginal smears are used for laboratory confirmation of BV, the diagnostic criteria for which are based on the standardized Nugent scoring system (319). For other infections, the Gram stain can play a key role in guiding the extent of culture workup. More importantly, these results can indicate the presence of a polymicrobial infectious process, enabling physicians to ensure that empiric antimicrobial therapy includes coverage for anaerobes including Gram-positive non-spore-forming bacteria. Laboratorians and clinicians alike should be aware of the potential for atypical Gram stain morphologies, e.g., coccoid cells of Actinomyces radicidentis, which can resemble staphylococci (98, 320), and the Gram-negative appearance of many genera of anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods (e.g., many Eubacteriaceae genera) (254).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: A variety of selective media can be employed based on the expected microbiota at the collection site or, in the case of bite wounds, on the oral microbiota of the attacker (human or animal). Fresh or prereduced culture media, including phenylethyl alcohol blood agar and/or colistin-nalidixic acid blood agar, can be useful for enhanced recovery rates of Gram-positive organisms if so desired (321). The growth of many asaccharolytic species on solid media is enhanced by the addition of 0.5% arginine (322). In general, current and alternatively named members of the genera Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus can be selectively cultured using agar media with an acidic pH, such as Rogosa or MRS (de Man, Rogosa, and Sharpe) agar, though some more fastidious strains may not grow on these media. Conventional blood agar and blood culture media should recover most lactobacilli acceptably well.

Several anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods are able to grow under aerobic conditions, though anaerobic culture incubation is recommended for optimal recovery. The principles and practice of anaerobic cultures are discussed inchapter 53. Differences between commercial blood culture systems exist with respect to their ability to recover anaerobes, including anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods (323).

There are several noteworthy special considerations for culturing prosthetic joint-associated specimens (324). Bacteria, including anaerobes, form biofilms on prosthetic material, and dislodgement of these bacteria has been shown to increase the sensitivity of organism detection compared with culture of periprosthetic tissue and fluid cultures (325). The most widely reported method to accomplish this dislodgement is sonication, and the optimal cutoff value for sonicate cultures appears to be ≥5 CFU on any one piece of agar medium (326). Sonication of the prosthesis in bags leads to excessive contamination, and sonication should instead be performed using a solid container (327). Sonication showed sensitivity inferior to that of tissue culture for fracture-related infections in a recently published meta-analysis (328). Alternative methods for biofilm dislodgement have been published and include vortex mixing, bead mill processing (329) and pretreatment with dithiothreitol (DTT) (330), though the acceptability of these methods compared to sonication is less well established (331). One recent study found that DTT pretreatment had lower sensitivity than sonication (74% versus 43%, respectively) (332).

Several studies showed that the sensitivity of periprosthetic culture for the diagnosis of PJI is improved by inoculation of the homogenized/ground tissue into blood culture bottles: a 47% improvement in sensitivity was observed compared to conventional agar and broth cultures (92.1% versus 62.6%, respectively) (333), and this method has been shown to be associated with reduced operating costs compared to traditional culture workflows. Though guidelines from the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) recommend that five or six periprosthetic samples be cultured for patients where PJI is suspected (334), the optimal number of specimens was shown to be three periprosthetic tissue specimens when these are inoculated into blood culture bottles, compared to four specimens using standard plate and broth cultures (335). The optimal incubation period for prosthetic-joint-associated cultures has been controversial, in part because of conflicting data regarding the requirement for extended culture incubation periods for the isolation of C. acnes in vitro (336). The optimal culture incubation has not yet been defined, as a number of studies reported a need for a 14-day incubation period (337, 338), while other studies have shown that a 7-day incubation period is sufficient when anaerobic thioglycolate is used (339) and a 10-day incubation is adequate when only plated media are used (340). However, in one study, a 14-day incubation period was required for the recovery of C. acnes for both anaerobic thioglycolate and blood culture bottles into which periprosthetic specimens were inoculated (333). The time to recovery of C. acnes differs widely between blood culture bottle types (341) and manufacturers (342). In a recent study examining the performance of the BacT/Alert Virtuo system, isolation of Cutibacterium species occurred between 5 and 14 days of incubation (342). Thus, the optimal incubation period and culture period for the isolation of C. acnes from prosthetic joint and blood culture specimens remains to be fully defined. Interestingly, some data suggest that extended incubation might not be required for the isolation of C. acnes from CSF specimens (343). The potential reasons for these differences in apparent required incubation time are unclear.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Traditionally, identification of bacterial isolates in clinical microbiology laboratories has been performed using phenotypic tests. Among the anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods, a number of organisms are known to be relatively inert and thus not reliably identified by phenotypic methods (e.g.,Eubacterium and closely related species). Nevertheless, many laboratories have for many years relied on commercially available phenotypic identification systems for the identification of anaerobes, which is now being superseded by MALDI-TOF MS. The advent of 16S rRNA gene sequencing has revealed that phenotypic identification methods can be problematic for certain anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods. With the advent of whole-genome sequencing, taxonomic relationships have been revealed to be even more complex, though this method is not widely used by most clinical laboratories for organism identification.

sect1.title: Presumptive Identification
sect1.para: Initial characterization of an unknown isolate typically involves an assessment of aerotolerance (growth in air or in air plus 5% CO2), colonial morphology, the presence or absence of hemolysis, pigmentation, and fluorescence under long-wave UV illumination (365-nm wavelength). Colony morphology may provide clues regarding the organism involved; for instance, a “molar tooth” appearance is typical for A. israelii, A. gerencseriae, B. nasicola, A. oricola, A. propionica, S. wiggsiae, and E. nodatum, whereas colonies from other Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces members can exhibit a “breadcrumb” appearance (104). A. graevenitzii may produce both molar-toothed and smooth, entire colonies. However, most species discussed in this chapter produce small, relatively nondescript colonies. A number of anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods are capable of fluorescence and/or pigment production: A. graevenitzii, A. propionica, and E. lenta show orange or red fluorescence under UV light (174, 344), and pink/red pigmentation of colonies is typical for S. odontolytica (345). However, other Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces spp. can also produce pigment, especially on rabbit laked blood agar, with A. graevenitzii appearing as nearly black, A. radicidentis as brown, and A. urogenitalis as reddish colonies (100).

An assessment of Gram stain morphology can also contribute to a presumptive identification, although laboratorians should be aware of organisms that produce an unexpected Gram stain morphology or those that stain Gram negative either by nature or by being easily overdecolorized. Examples of this include more recently described nonbranching species ofActinomyces (98, 346), as well as F. alocis and M. mulieris, which routinely stain Gram negative (72, 347). Actinotignum, Eubacterium, and other closely related species show Gram variability when older (>3-day-old) cultures are used for staining. Overdecolorization of Gram-positive organisms can also occur due to exposure to oxygen or to damage from fixatives and reagents causing a breakdown of the physical integrity of the cell wall. Thus, limiting the time of exposure to oxygen between incubation and staining improves the reliability of the Gram stain for anaerobic bacteria (348). Because of the possibility of overdecolorization, confirmation of the Gram reaction may be required using either the string test with a solution of 3% potassium hydroxide (349) or use of special-potency antibiotic susceptibility disks (350); Gram-positive species are generally resistant to colistin (10 μg) and susceptible to vancomycin (5 μg) and often to kanamycin (1 mg). The intrinsic resistance of some Lactobacillus species/strains, e.g., L. rhamnosus, to glycopeptides should be taken into consideration.

Additional rapid tests for initial grouping of non-spore-forming, Gram-positive anaerobes include testing for production of catalase (H2O2 at a concentration of 15%), indole, nitrate reduction, and motility (351). Depending on the specimen site and the number of isolates recovered in culture, a presumptive identification to the genus level may suffice. Identification to the species level should ideally be performed whenever non-spore-forming anaerobic Gram-positive rods are present in pure cultures in clinical specimens or as the predominant organism from normally sterile sites.

sect1.title: Biochemical Testing
sect1.para: Identification of anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods to the species level historically involved phenotypic characterization based on sugar fermentation reactions and enzymatic profiles, the latter being performed with individual diagnostic tablets, fluorogenic substrate tests, or preformed enzyme kits. This approach has been shown to be problematic from several standpoints. First, insufficient growth and poor reproducibility of reactions cause difficulties in interpretation of results obtained with biochemical tests (100). Use of young cultures and a heavy inoculum was recommended for biochemical testing, with extended incubation (up to 48 h) required for some strains. Second, changing taxonomy within this group of organisms led to the discovery that traditional biochemical approaches lack sufficient specificity for accurate identification in many cases. For example, members of the A. naeslundii/Actinomyces viscosus group cannot be individually differentiated by phenotypic tests alone. Biochemical reactions for a number of the genera discussed in this chapter are shown in Tables 2 to 5. However, many of the papers upon which these tables are based reported results for only a single isolate or a limited number of isolates, and different reaction results have been observed in subsequent studies in a number of cases. Readers should also be aware that ascertaining reactions based on commercial phenotypic systems (described in the next paragraph) can vary from the results shown in Tables 2 to 5. Phenotypic criteria are particularly unreliable for identification of many Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces species and members of the L. acidophilus complex and related species (352). In one study which retrospectively applied 16S rRNA gene sequencing to 66 isolates identified biochemically as Lactobacillus isolates, 27% were actually Actinomyces, Clostridium, Bifidobacterium, Weissella, or Carnobacterium species (246).

The use of gas-liquid chromatography (GLC) to determine the major volatile fatty acid end products of glucose metabolism in a given isolate was previously an important method for assigning a genus-level identification to a given organism. However, use of this method also required extended incubation of the organism (351). In addition, GLC analysis of cellular fatty acids and examination of protein patterns by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis have been used taxonomically to distinguish among strains within a species and among organisms within a genus or family. Despite its utility, GLC was not a method that was widely available in most clinical laboratories.

For the aforementioned reasons, the availability of commercial identification systems for anaerobic bacteria was an important development in the ability of clinical laboratories to identify anaerobic bacteria. These systems, in essence, miniaturized the assessment of enzymatic and carbohydrate fermentation profiles. A variety of these are available from a number of manufacturers and include API ID 32A (bioMérieux, Marcy-l’Etoile, France), RapID Ana II (Remel, Lenexa, KS), BBL Crystal anaerobe ID kits (Becton Dickinson Diagnostic Systems), and the Vitek 2 ANC ID card (bioMérieux). These systems have been historically adopted by many clinical laboratories, as they are easier to use and in many cases have a considerably shorter turnaround time than conventional phenotypic testing, with some systems requiring only a 4-h incubation. Like traditional biochemical methods, these systems typically require a heavy inoculum (3 to 4 McFarland optical density). A major limitation of these systems has been the lack of adequate representation of organisms in the database of reactions used to make the identification (353). It is also important to note that the same analyte for a given isolate can produce different results when tested by different commercial systems.

It is recommended that identification systems being validated for use in the clinical laboratory be capable of correctly identifying >90% of the isolates tested (354). However, the results of studies investigating the performance of these systems have showed variable performance for anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods, with reported species-level identification accuracies ranging from <30% to >90% for this group of bacteria depending on the study (355, 356). These studies have several limitations, including the lack of adequate representation of anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods being tested, including only organisms targeted by the system database, and using phenotypic rather than genotypic reference identification methods. Higher identification rates are reported when the organisms tested are limited to those contained within the database (355). When the performance of the BBL Crystal anaerobe, RapID Ana II, and Vitek 2 ANC systems were directly compared for anaerobic Gram-positive non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods, these systems correctly identified the isolates tested to the species level in 29.4%, 35.3%, and 52.9% of cases, respectively, compared with GLC analysis (357). Misidentification rates of 5.9%, 47.1%, and 11.8% were observed for these organisms with the BBL Crystal anaerobe, RapID Ana II, and Vitek 2 ANC systems, respectively. When the results of testing with the Vitek 2 ANC card were compared with those of 16S rRNA gene sequencing, 60.1% and 79.4% of isolates tested were correctly identified to the genus and species levels, respectively (358). While correct species-level identification rates of 90% were observed for organisms that are present within the database, a misidentification rate of 84% was observed for organisms tested that were not present in the system database, with only 47% correctly identified to the genus level (358).

Many studies have tended to predominantly includeActinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces species, Lactobacillus and alternatively named Lactobacillus species, and Cutibacterium. As a result, the performance of these systems for other less commonly encountered genera is less well known. B. scardovii was readily separated from other bifidobacteria using the API ID 32A kit in one study (187), and B. scardovii and B. longum were frequently misidentified as Actinomyces species by the RapID Ana II system, with A. omnicolens being unidentified (188). The Vitek 2 ANC card appears to accurately identify E. lenta and Bifidobacterium (355) but overall appears to be unreliable for identifying species that are current and alternatively named Actinomyces genus members. P. lymphophilum was misidentified as S. meyeri by the Vitek ANC card (171). Misidentification of Actinomyces to the species level were commonly observed for the RapID Ana II system (359). Isolates of F. vaginae have been misidentified as Gemella morbillorum by the API ID 32A and RapID ANA II (Remel) test kits (197, 360). The carbohydrate fermentation test kit API 50 CH (bioMérieux), which is specifically designed for lactobacilli, can be valuable in identification to the genus level but lacks specificity at the species level (361). API 32A misidentified E. lenta as Clostridium and C. avidum as C. acnes. Thus, laboratories should be aware of the limitations of these anaerobic identification systems and of the possibility for misidentification, with misidentifications at the genus level having the potential for deleterious consequences for the selection of empiric antimicrobial therapy.

sect1.title: Identification by DNA Sequence Analysis
sect1.para: Sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene became the gold standard for accurate species identification (362), with the first approximately 500 bp of the 5′ region of the gene being most commonly used (363). DNA extraction from isolates growing in culture is the first step of this process, and extraction of DNA from Gram-positive organism frequently requires additional measures to lyse the cells that are not usually required for Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., use of lysozyme). The entire process can also be performed directly from clinical samples when appropriate (364). Sequencing of the amplified DNA is followed by an alignment of the obtained sequence with sequences within a database (365). Both commercial and public databases are available for this purpose. Public databases are often inadequately curated (e.g., NCBI), so that some sequences contained therein may be incorrectly or inappropriately assigned to a given species or even genus. Published guidelines for assigning an organism identification based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing are available (366), as are many scientific papers and reviews.

table.title: TABLE 2 Biochemical characteristics of Actinomyces and related bacteria encountered in human infectionsa

bA. gravenitzii colonies are non-pigmented on Brucella agar but almost black on rabbit laked blood, whereas other pigment-producing Actinomcyes species appear as pinkish/brownish colonies on Brucella agar and darker colonies on rabbit laked blood.
