dAbbreviations: Mal, maltose; Man, mannitol; Raf, raffinose; Suc, sucrose; Tre, trehalose.

Although 16S rRNA gene sequencing has become the gold standard for organism identification, not all organisms can be taxonomically separated using the 16S rRNA gene. Thus, sequencing of other housekeeping genes (e.g.,metG) or even multilocus sequence typing was required for certain organisms, e.g., A. naeslundii, A. johnsonii, and A. oris (367). More recently, WGS has emerged as a disruptive technology that is replacing 16S rRNA gene sequencing as the new gold standard for organism identification (368, 369), though it is not yet widely available in the majority of clinical microbiology laboratories. Whereas 16S rRNA gene sequencing may not adequately distinguish between certain bacterial species, WGS exhibits far greater discriminatory power with respect to both organism identification and strain typing. The use of NGS methodologies combined with 16S rRNA gene PCR has led to characterization of the microbiota of various sites within the human body as well as the discovery of novel bacteria across many taxonomic orders (370–374). The primers used for 16S rRNA gene amplification as well as the methodologies used for NGS can themselves introduce bias if used on polymicrobial specimens (375). Nevertheless, WGS and microbiome characterization are undoubtedly on track to be more widely used in the field of clinical microbiology in the future.

sect1.title: Identification by MALDI-TOF MS
sect1.para: MALDI-TOF MS has revolutionized the field of clinical microbiology by enabling laboratories to rapidly and accurately identify routine isolates of bacteria and yeasts (376, 377). Implementation of MALDI-TOF MS for routine organism identification leads to dramatic increases in the number of organisms that can be identified within the first day of culture workup compared with traditional phenotypic identification methods (87.2% versus 9.4%, respectively) (378). There are two MALDI-TOF MS systems that are FDA cleared for in vitro diagnostic (IVD) use in the United States: the MALDI Biotyper CA system (Bruker Daltonics GmbH, Bremen, Germany) and the Vitek MS (bioMérieux; previously Shimadzu). Both systems are also available with research-use-only (RUO) databases, which are additionally capable of having user-built database additions and customization. Guidelines have been published on the use of MALDI-TOF MS for organism identification by clinical laboratories (379). At the time of writing, both of these FDA-cleared databases have a relative paucity of broad representation of the organisms discussed in this chapter. In the case of the Bruker CA system, there is wide representation of alternatively named Actinomyces members in the manufacturer’s list of claimed bacteria, whereas there is almost zero representation of alternatively named Propionibacterium members. Similarly, reference spectra for only 5 Lactobacillus species are present in this database. In contrast, while the Vitek MS system has no lactobacilli as “claimed” organisms, it has over 20 Lactobacillus species present, but these are considered “unclaimed” and thus require additional testing. The Vitek MS system is unable to differentiate between A. schaalii and A. sanguinis. If a clinical laboratory is using an FDA-cleared system, it would be prudent to review the constituent members of the databases in use to assess and mitigate against relevant dearths in organism coverage.

A number of important elements have emerged regarding the performance of MALDI-TOF MS for identification of anaerobes including anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods. First, extraction of the cellular proteins appears to be required for optimal performance, though this requirement is far more pronounced for the Bruker system. This extraction can be performed by an overlay of formic acid prior to the addition of matrix (on target) or by full tube extraction (with ethanol, acetonitrile, and formic acid) (380). Extraction was associated with improved performance for the Bruker Biotyper with both tube and on-target extraction methods (380). Second, multiple studies have shown that the performance of the RUO databases can be improved by lowering the threshold of the identification score used for species-level as well as genus-level identifications. Use of a score of ≥1.9 instead of the manufacturer-recommended ≥2.0 led to correct species-level identification rates of 92.5% for Actinobacteria tested with the Bruker Biotyper (n = 417) (381). Last, performance has been shown to improve as the databases are further developed in terms of breadth and depth of organism coverage and representation. The performance of MALDI-TOF MS for anaerobic bacteria does not appear to be influenced by exposure to oxygen (382).

Most published data on the performance of MALDI-TOF MS for the identification of anaerobes (including non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods) involved RUO rather than the IVD-cleared databases. Early studies showed suboptimal rates of identification for anaerobes (67.2% and 49% for the Bruker and Vitek MS, respectively) (383). Importantly, these studies reported that identifications were not obtained for Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces, Bifidobacterium, Eggerthella, Blautia, Solobacterium, or Turicibacter (383), with A. israelii misidentified as Lactobacillus (now Eggerthia) catenaformis (384). Use of identification score thresholds lower than those recommended by the manufacturers (e.g., 1.8) led to increased rates of identification but also increased rates of misidentification (7.9% and 1.4% for Bruker and Vitek MS, respectively) (383). Subsequent studies using expanded databases have shown improved overall performance for several of the aforementioned organisms. Using a user-built database, Schmitt and colleagues successfully identified S. moorei, Bulleidia, Eggerthella, Alloscardovia, and A. schaalii (80). Whereas earlier versions of the Bruker MALDI Biotyper database were unable to identify S. moorei, Turicibacter species, or Collinsella species (385), later versions are now able to do so (381).

Nevertheless, expansion of the databases does not always equate to improved performance characteristics for all organisms equally, with some organisms remaining unidentified due to insufficient database expansion. For one large reference laboratory in the United States, the most common anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods not identifiable by MALDI-TOF MS includedA. schaalii, W. neuii, C. hongkongensis, and A. israelii (386). Misidentifications can still occur despite database expansions; Mogibacterium species were misidentified as Clostridium halophilum and Parvimonas micra was misidentified as S. exigua by the Bruker Biotyper (387, 388). Similarly, Schaalia georgiae was misidentified as Capnocytophaga gingivalis by the Vitek MS. In studies examining lactobacilli isolated from clinical sources, the Bruker Biotyper MS system provided 85 to 93% concordance at the species level with 16S rRNA gene PCR or sequence-based identification. Discordance was largely due to no MALDI-TOF MS identification or L. casei misidentified as L. paracasei (235, 389).

There is a paucity of published studies investigating the performance of the IVD-cleared databases for anaerobes, and within those studies, there is often very limited representation of non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods. The Vitek MS v2.0 database system correctly identified 91.5% of 265 Gram-positive anaerobes; however, only 66 to 86% ofActinomyces species tested were correctly identified to the species level (390). The Bruker Biotyper MS system reported 98.5% correct species-level identifications for anaerobes, with a 0.8% misidentification rate (391). Nevertheless, this study included only Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces and Cutibacterium species and did not include details on the specific performance of the system for these individual genera. Importantly, despite the successful application of “early MALDI” to aerobic bacteria growing from positive blood cultures (i.e., MALDI performed after a few hours of subculture on agar plates), this method does not appear to work well for anaerobic bacteria (386).

A direct comparison of the performance of the Biotyper and Vitek MS systems that are cleared for IVD use in Europe showed correct species-level identification rates of 58.2% and 60.7% forActinomycetaceae, respectively (133). Important differences appear to exist between the systems with respect to the identification of specific bacterial species: whereas the Bruker system correctly identified 81% of Actinotignum isolates to the species level, the Vitek MS produced no identification for 66.7% of isolates, with a 33.3% genus-level misidentification rate. Similar species-level identification rates were observed between the systems (approximately 60%), and neither system was able to identify Varibaculum. Genus-level misidentifications occurred more commonly with the Vitek MS system: a number of Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces isolates were misidentified as C. avidum, and the Actinotignum isolates were individually misidentified as a large array of organisms (e.g., Streptococcus agalactiae, Gemella morbillorum, Listeria grayi, and S. meyeri). These genus-level misidentifications occurred more frequently with on-target extraction than with direct deposit. However, reanalysis with an updated database (IVD 3.0) appeared to resolve this issue. One large study that specifically addressed the performance of the Vitek MS system for invasive Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces isolates found that Vitek MS identified only 50% of isolates tested to the genus and/or species level, with 37% of isolates unidentified and 13% discordant results with a reported “excellent ID” at a probability of 99% (111). These discordant identifications included Clostridium perfringens, Escherichia coli, Kocuria kristinae, Kytococcus sedentarius, Arcanobacterium haemolyticum, Streptococcus mitis, Geobacillus thermoglucosidasius, Paracoccus yeei, Staphylococcus warneri, and Cedecea neteri. 16S rRNA gene sequencing should therefore be used for Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces species identification until MALDI-TOF MS databases are sufficiently optimized for these organisms.

Despite these limitations, the performance of MALDI-TOF MS has been shown overall to be superior to that of commercial phenotypic systems, with higher rates of correct species-level identifications and lower misidentification rates (392–394). MALDI-TOF MS has enabled laboratories to rapidly and accurately identify several non-spore-forming anaerobic Gram-positive rods that previously could often be accurately identified only by 16S rRNA gene sequencing, including A. schaalii, Bifidobacterium, Alloscardovia, Atopobium, Slackia, and Eggerthella species (195, 218, 381). As the manufacturer databases are further developed and expanded, MALDI-TOF MS is likely to lead to an improved understanding of disease associations with this group of organisms. More recently, a large meta-analysis comparing the Vitek MS and Bruker Biotyper systems showed correct-identification rates of >90% for both systems (388). However, individual genus-level identification rates can be substantially lower. MALDI-TOF MS can also be used for organism identification directly from positive blood cultures; the Bruker Sepsityper system was shown to correctly identify 70.8% of Gram-positive anaerobes from Bactec and BacT/Alert blood culture bottles in one study (342). A recent analysis of the performance of the Bruker Biotyper V6 database for approximately 1,400 anaerobic Gram-positive rods showed 95.8% being correctly identified to the species level, with only 2.6% of isolates producing an unreliable or no identification (395). Users of MALDI-TOF MS should therefore be cognizant of what anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods are covered in the database used in their laboratory in addition to the possible limitations of MALDI-TOF MS for identification of this group of bacteria.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Serologic tests have no diagnostic value for this group of organisms.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Empiric antimicrobial therapy (e.g., metronidazole) is often administered by the treating physician when anaerobic bacteria are suspected to be the cause of a patient’s infection (396). Anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods can frequently be isolated as part of a polymicrobial infection, and a large number of anaerobes (≥5) may be recovered in culture. Individual susceptibility testing in this scenario is likely to be unhelpful clinically and should be discouraged. Instead, susceptibility testing for these bacteria should be performed when a given organism is isolated in pure culture or is predominant. The source of the specimen (i.e., a specimen from a sterile site versus one likely to be contaminated with the normal microbiota) should also be factored into the decision to pursue susceptibility testing.

Susceptibility testing methods and breakpoints for anaerobes have been defined by both the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) and the European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) (397, 398). There are several important differences between these organizations with respect to their guidance on anaerobic susceptibility testing as well as important technical differences between the two sets of guidelines. Firstly, CLSI has combined breakpoints for both Gram-positive and Gram-negative anaerobes, whereas EUCAST has a limited number of anaerobic genus-specific breakpoints, with breakpoints available for C. acnes. EUCAST has also published a separate set of suggested interpretive criteria for anaerobes more generally which they state can be used for Actinomyces, Bifidobacterium, Eggerthella, Eubacterium, and Lactobacillus species. These suggested breakpoints are based on previously used anaerobic breakpoints and those for other species. Secondly, the breakpoints themselves vary between EUCAST and CLSI. For example, EUCAST does not have breakpoints for cephalosporins or fluoroquinolones, while CLSI has breakpoints for several cephalosporins and moxifloxacin. Similarly, CLSI has breakpoints for tetracyclines, whereas EUCAST guidance indicates that while tetracyclines may have efficacy for the treatment of intra-abdominal infections, MICs do not appear to correlate with clinical outcome, and thus, no breakpoints have been defined. Readers should also be aware that even when breakpoints exist for a particular agent, they can differ by more than two dilutions between both organizations in some cases (e.g., ampicillin).

EUCAST previously recommended that susceptibility testing forLactobacillus species be performed under anaerobic conditions, whereas CLSI has Lactobacillus-specific breakpoints and recommends that susceptibility testing for this genus be performed in cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton broth with lysed horse blood (2.5 to 5% [vol/vol]) incubated under aerobic conditions (with 5% CO2) (399). For other anaerobes (including anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods), CLSI MIC breakpoints are defined using agar dilution with brucella agar supplemented with hemin, vitamin K1, and laked sheep blood (5% [vol/vol]). Microbroth dilution is recommended only for Bacteroides and Parabacteroides species. EUCAST now recommends agar dilution but using fastidious anaerobe agar, with disk diffusion criteria published for selected genera. In reality, agar dilution is technically challenging, and thus, many laboratories instead use gradient diffusion strips (e.g., E-test or Liofilchem). Testing by gradient diffusion has been shown to be reliable for anaerobes; 98% of organisms tested had MICs within 2 doubling dilutions of the reference method, and a ≤2% very major/major error rate was observed (400, 401). However, there are reports of false resistance to metronidazole that appears to be medium and incubation condition dependent (402). Finally, some novel antibacterial agents have been approved for clinical use in recent years. In some cases, they appear to be potent against anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods (e.g., eravacycline) (403); in other cases, they lack potency against these organisms and have high MICs (e.g., cefiderocol) (404). In all cases, there are no CLSI or EUCAST breakpoints for anaerobes for these antibiotics.

For the aforementioned reasons, antimicrobial susceptibility for a given anaerobic organism may often be inferred based on the bacterial identification, as susceptibility testing may be performed at a reference laboratory or, if performed in-house, requires incubation for up to 48 h. Published data regarding antimicrobial susceptibilities of anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods can be difficult to interpret and are complicated by changes in bacterial taxonomy (405). Issues with the accuracy of identifications obtained by commercial identification systems should also be taken into account.

Metronidazole is commonly used as both empiric and definite therapy for many anaerobic infections. As discussed above, several genera may be capable of growth under aerobic conditions and are intrinsically resistant to metronidazole. Several members of the generaCutibacterium (Propionibacterium), Actinotignum, Actinobaculum, Actinomyces (and alternatively named Actinomyces genus members), and Lactobacillus (and alternatively named Lactobacillus genus members) are generally intrinsically resistant to metronidazole (117, 406–409). F. vaginae and M. curtisii have high rates of resistance to metronidazole, whereas rates of metronidazole resistance are variable for M. mulieris as well as members of the genera Eggerthella and Eubacterium (130). It is unknown whether the metronidazole resistance of F. vaginae or M. curtisii is what accounts for treatment failures in patients with BV (197, 410). Susceptibility to vancomycin is considered a universal characteristic of Gram-positive organisms. However, resistance to vancomycin and other glycopeptides is common among members of the genus Lactobacillus and related bacteria (see below). Reduced susceptibility to vancomycin has been observed among Flavonifractor strains (MIC, 4 to 8 μg/ml) (63); the vanB gene has been detected among some strains of A. minutum (208).

Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces species are generally considered universally susceptible to penicillin and generally have low MICs for other beta-lactams. Susceptibility to clindamycin is variable, with resistance observed for 17 to 33% of strains (411, 412). The majority of data on susceptibility for Actinotignum and Actinobaculum are derived from A. schaalii, which exhibits low MICs for beta-lactams and vancomycin (117, 122) but MICs to erythromycin and clindamycin that have been attributed to the presence of an ermX phenotype (413). However, high MICs are often observed for both ciprofloxacin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (SXT), though MICs to levofloxacin can be in the susceptible range among these isolates. Mobiluncus species are considered susceptible to penicillin, clindamycin, and vancomycin. Like Actinomyces, Cutibacterium species have almost universal susceptibility to penicillin but variable susceptibility to clindamycin. One recent study showed that fluoroquinolone resistance in Cutibacterium (gyrA) can be easily selected in vitro, though the clinical significance of this finding is unknown (414). The ermX gene, conferring macrolide and clindamycin resistance, was noted to be present in 92.6% of C. avidum strains analyzed, with many strains found to be multidrug resistant (415). In addition to the intrinsic resistance to metronidazole, P. lymphophilum has also been found to have high MICs to both levofloxacin and SXT but low MICs for beta-lactam antibiotics (170, 171).

High rates of ciprofloxacin resistance have been observed amongBifidobacterium species, with variable susceptibility to metronidazole observed (20% resistance) (177). Though most isolates have low MICs to clindamycin, vancomycin, and many beta-lactams, penicillin resistance was observed in >40% of strains in one study, along with variable susceptibility to cefoxitin (411). In one study looking at anaerobic susceptibility test results from isolates between 2012 and 2019, Bifidobacterium had susceptibility rates of 84 to 85% for cefoxitin and clindamycin, with 100% susceptibility to piperacillin-tazobactam (416).

Low MICs to β-lactams, glycopeptides, tetracyclines, and cotrimoxazole and linezolid have been observed forAlloscardovia. High MICs (≥256 μg/ml) were observed for both erythromycin and clindamycin in one strain, which was attributed to a single point mutation in 23S rRNA, along with acquired fluoroquinolone resistance, which was associated with a parC mutation (417). Though isolates of Eggerthella are susceptible to metronidazole, high rates of resistance to both penicillin and ceftriaxone have been observed, along with variable susceptibility to piperacillin-tazobactam, clindamycin, and moxifloxacin (219).

Although vancomycin and teicoplanin are considered active against most Gram-positive bacteria, species-related resistance to glycopeptides is frequent among species of current and alternatively named members of the genusLactobacillus. Less than one-quarter of the isolates from 80 cases of Lactobacillus infections were reported as susceptible to vancomycin (234). For Lactobacillus spp., the antimicrobial susceptibility profiles can be clustered into several patterns, two of which are vancomycin resistant and two of which are vancomycin susceptible (418). L. fermentum, L. salivarius, and L. vaginalis are consistently resistant to vancomycin, while L. casei/L. paracasei and L. rhamnosus are consistently resistant to vancomycin and have elevated MICs for cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, and ertapenem. The L. gasseri/L. johnsonii group and L. jensenii are typically susceptible to vancomycin but may show elevated MICs for fluoroquinolones and daptomycin (235, 239, 418). L. acidophilus, L. crispatus, L. iners, L. delbrueckii, and other infrequently encountered lactobacilli have tested vancomycin susceptible but may be linezolid resistant (418). Generally, lactobacilli test susceptible to penicillin and ampicillin but can have a broad range of MICs for the cephalosporins, including cefuroxime and ceftriaxone. Erythromycin, clindamycin, and imipenem usually have activity, but occasional isolates test resistant (419).

Daptomycin MICs vary widely among members of the anaerobic non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods. MIC90s as high as >32 μg/ml were noted for S. odontolytica, with MIC90s of 8 μg/ml seen for a number of other species (e.g., S. meyeri) (420). However, many of these elevated MICs were observed when daptomycin susceptibility testing was performed in the absence of calcium supplementation. In the presence of calcium, daptomycin MIC90s were low for Bifidobacterium and Cutibacterium species (0.5 and 2.0 μg/ml, respectively), though they continued to be elevated for Actinomyces, alternatively named Actinomyces species, and Eubacterium lentum (4 and 16 μg/ml, respectively) (421). Telavancin was highly active against strains of Actinomyces, Eubacterium, and Cutibacterium tested, with MIC90s of <0.25 μg/ml, though L. casei appeared to be intrinsically resistant to this agent (420). The related lipoglycopeptide dalbavancin had low MIC90s for Actinomyces and alternatively named Actinomyces species, Eubacterium, and Cutibacterium, though high MIC90s were observed for the Lactobacillus and former Lactobacillus strains tested in one study (>32 μg/ml) (421). Variable MIC90s to dalbavancin were observed for Actinomyces and Lactobacillus species. While low MIC90s to clarithromycin were observed for Actinomyces species, variable MIC90s were noted for Lactobacillus species, with high-level resistance observed for Eubacterium species (422).

One report found metronidazole resistance to be uncommon amongSlackia species, though all isolates tested were resistant to SXT (226). However, other reports have noted resistance to metronidazole for S. exigua (227, 423). In contrast, isolates of C. hongkongensis are metronidazole susceptible but resistant to cefotaxime, with variable MICs to penicillin observed (261). S. moorei was frequently resistant to SXT in one study (305) but was susceptible to beta-lactams, clindamycin, and metronidazole in another study (303). A recent analysis of 24 isolates found universal susceptibility to beta-lactams and metronidazole, with >90% of isolates testing resistant to rifampin and an 11.8% rate of resistance to moxifloxacin (306).

E. tayi may not grow well for susceptibility testing in standard brucella broth; three isolates of E. tayi tested to date showed susceptibility to metronidazole, penicillin, ampicillin, piperacillin, mezlocillin, ampicillin/sulbactam, amoxicillin/clavulanate, piperacillin/tazobactam, cefotetan, cefoxitin, imipenem, meropenem, clindamycin, and chloramphenicol, but one isolate had an intermediate-range MIC to tetracycline (48). For Lachnoanaerobaculum spp., susceptibility data exist only for the type strains, which tested in the susceptible range to penicillin G (MIC ≤ 0.5 μg/ml) (51). The limited number of R. peoriensis isolates tested to date have been resistant to penicillin; variably susceptible to clindamycin; susceptible to piperacillin-tazobactam, amoxicillin-clavulanate, meropenem, ertapenem, and metronidazole; and negative for beta-lactamase production by the nitrocefin disc assay (266–268).

In the one case report ofS. satelles infection, the isolate had MICs of ≤0.5 μg/ml to penicillin, clindamycin, metronidazole, ampicillin, ceftriaxone, piperacillin/tazobactam, and ertapenem (286). In summary, readers should be aware of the lack of adequate data for less commonly encountered species. For many species, data points are limited to only a few strains and lack clinical outcome correlations. In general, while penicillin and other β-lactams are generally considered to have high rates of susceptibility among anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods, universal susceptibility for this class should not be assumed (411, 424, 425).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Infections with anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods are frequently polymicrobial. Interpretation of the clinical significance of the isolation of individual members of this group in the context of a polymicrobial infection can be challenging, though isolation of these organisms from sterile sites is considered clinically significant. Because of the proximity of many infections to mucocutaneous surfaces, results should be interpreted in the context of whether contamination with commensal members of the microbiota was likely. Similarly, direct Gram stain results should be used to guide the extent of workup. Importantly, IDSA guidelines advise against performing identification and susceptibility testing of each isolate isolated from polymicrobial infections (426). Instead, the guidelines recommend that a general description of the culture results be provided (e.g., mixed aerobic and anaerobic intestinal microbiota) along with selective identification of certain organisms where resistance is known to occur. Furthermore, these guidelines specify that susceptibility testing should be performed on clinically significant isolates and not on all bacteria isolated in culture. However, laboratories should also be aware of not overlooking certain bacteria in the context of a polymicrobial process: current and alternatively named Actinomyces genus members are generally isolated in conjunction with other bacterial species, yet their presence should be made known to the treating physician.

Pus collected from patients where actinomycosis is suspected should be examined both macroscopically and microscopically for the presence of sulfur granules; if they are present, this should be reported as confirmation of a clinical history consistent with actinomycosis. Culture ofActinomyces or related genera alone from a site where the specimen is likely to have been contaminated with the commensal microbiota should be interpreted with caution. This is particularly the case for the head and neck regions, since Actinomyces and related genera are among the predominant genera within the normal oral microbiota.

Laboratories performing anaerobic cultures should ensure that sufficient culture incubation times are used. Premature reporting of only the fastest-growing species can be misleading, since growth ratesin vivo and in vitro may be very different. Incubation should be continued for at least 7 days before the final report is issued. In the case of PJI as well as VP shunt infections, some studies suggest that a 14-day culture incubation period be used to optimize recovery of Cutibacterium species.

The continuing improvement of MALDI-TOF MS databases for the identification of anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods is likely to further improve our understanding of the potential disease associations with members of this group of bacteria. Furthermore, improved accuracy of identification will ultimately also lead to better characterization of the antimicrobial susceptibility profiles of less commonly encountered members of the anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-positive rods. In the interim, laboratorians and clinicians alike need to be aware of existing issues with identification and antimicrobial susceptibility for this group of bacteria as well as the unique challenges of interpreting the clinical significance of these organisms and optimally managing the infections they cause.
